title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DENVER – On a night when the rim must have looked as wide as the Rocky Mountains, Dale Ellis authored a masterpiece. The Seattle SuperSonics veteran turned back the clock with a breathtaking shooting display, pouring in a game-high 42 points to lead his team to a hard-fought 109-99 road victory over the Denver Nuggets.

From the opening tip, Ellis was in a rhythm that defied logic and defense. Every catch-and-shoot opportunity was a potential three points, and his quick release left defenders perpetually a step behind. He was a flamethrower on the perimeter, methodically dismantling Denver’s schemes and keeping the Sonics in control even as the Nuggets scrapped to stay close.

While Ellis provided the offensive fireworks, his teammates provided the necessary support. Gary Payton, the vocal leader, orchestrated the attack with 11 assists and chipped in 16 points, forming a potent inside-outside combination with the red-hot Ellis. Shawn Kemp anchored the paint with a powerful 17-point, 11-rebound double-double, ensuring Seattle controlled the interior battle.

The Nuggets, despite the offensive onslaught, refused to fade quietly into the night. Antonio McDyess battled valiantly for 20 points and 13 rebounds, while Bryant Stith provided a scoring punch with 22 points. Their efforts kept the home crowd engaged and the pressure on the Sonics until the final minutes.

But this night belonged to one man. Every time Denver threatened to close the gap, Ellis had an answer—a silky jumper from the corner, a dagger three from the top of the key. His 42-point explosion was a vintage performance, a reminder of his lethal scoring prowess and the driving force behind a crucial Seattle win on the road. It was a historic night, defined by the singular brilliance of Dale Ellis.
